article.title: Quantum Computing and Machine Learning for Cybersecurity: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) Attack Detection on Smart Micro-Grid

multiple_choice_question.text: What performance metrics are being visualized in Figure 1, showcasing the effectiveness of the QSVM model in detecting DDoS attacks?
choices: True Positives, True Negatives, False Positives

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key takeaway from Figure 2, comparing the normalized average values of accuracy, precision, and recall for QSVM and classical SVM?
choices: Classical SVM slightly outperforms QSVM in precision.
QSVM consistently demonstrates higher performance across all three metrics.
QSVM and classical SVM show comparable performance with negligible differences.
QSVM exhibits superior accuracy but lower precision and recall compared to classical SVM.

multiple_choice_question.text: What advantage does QSVM demonstrate over classical SVM based on the results depicted in Figure 3?
choices: QSVM achieves similar accuracy with significantly reduced execution time.
QSVM requires significantly less training data compared to classical SVM.
QSVM is less susceptible to overfitting than classical SVM.
QSVM is more robust to noisy data compared to classical SVM.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the confusion matrix, as shown in Table 3, primarily help to visualize and analyze in the context of machine learning models?
choices: The model\'s ability to correctly classify data instances into their respective classes.
The model\'s computational complexity and resource utilization.
The model\'s robustness to variations in input data distribution.
The model\'s generalization ability on unseen data.
